batchMetadata.description: Assessing risk of material misstatement, audit risk model, and planning considerations

questions.question: The audit risk model is expressed as AR = IR × CR × DR. What does DR represent?

options.B: Detection risk

questions.explanation: Detection risk (DR) is the risk that audit procedures will not detect a material misstatement. It is the only component of audit risk that auditors can directly control through the nature, timing, and extent of procedures. Inherent risk (IR) and control risk (CR) exist independently of the audit.
questions.tip: Audit risk components: IR and CR are entity-related (auditor assesses). DR is audit-related (auditor controls through procedures).

questions.question: If the auditor assesses inherent risk and control risk as high, what happens to acceptable detection risk?

options.A: Detection risk should be set high
options.B: Detection risk should be set low

questions.explanation: There is an inverse relationship between assessed IR/CR and acceptable DR. When IR and CR are high, the auditor must set DR low to maintain acceptable audit risk. Low DR requires more persuasive audit evidence (more extensive procedures, more reliable evidence, closer to year-end testing).
questions.tip: Inverse relationship: High IR/CR → Low DR needed → More audit work. Low IR/CR → Higher DR acceptable → Less work needed.

questions.question: Which factor would increase inherent risk for the inventory account?

options.A: Stable market prices for inventory items
options.B: Inventory consists of commodity items with quoted market prices
options.C: Inventory includes complex products requiring significant estimation
options.D: Management has extensive experience in the industry

questions.explanation: Inherent risk is higher when accounts involve estimates, judgments, or complex calculations. Inventory with complex products requiring estimation (for obsolescence, lower of cost or NRV) has higher inherent risk than commodities with readily determinable values. Stable prices and experienced management reduce inherent risk.
questions.tip: Higher inherent risk: Complexity, estimation, judgment, volatile markets, unusual transactions. Lower: Routine, objective, stable.

questions.question: An auditor assesses control risk at maximum. This means the auditor:

options.A: Will not perform any substantive procedures
options.B: Has determined controls are ineffective or has decided not to test them
options.D: Can rely entirely on controls for evidence

questions.explanation: Assessing control risk at maximum (100%) means the auditor either believes controls are not effective or has decided not to test controls (often because substantive procedures alone would be more efficient). This requires more extensive substantive testing to compensate. The auditor cannot skip substantive procedures.
questions.tip: CR at maximum: Either controls ineffective OR testing controls not efficient. Either way, rely on substantive procedures only.

questions.question: Risk of material misstatement (RMM) is defined as:

options.A: The risk that the auditor will express an incorrect opinion
options.B: The combined effect of inherent risk and control risk
options.D: The risk that fraud exists in the financial statements

questions.explanation: Risk of material misstatement (RMM) is the combined effect of inherent risk and control risk. It represents the risk that the financial statements are materially misstated prior to audit. RMM = IR × CR. Audit risk = RMM × DR. The auditor assesses RMM and adjusts procedures accordingly.
questions.tip: RMM = IR × CR (risk before audit). Audit Risk = RMM × DR (overall risk of wrong opinion).

questions.question: The overall audit strategy includes:

options.A: Detailed audit procedures for each account
options.B: Scope, timing, direction of the audit, and resource allocation

questions.explanation: The overall audit strategy sets the scope, timing, and direction of the audit and guides development of the detailed audit plan. It includes determining resources needed, materiality, preliminary risk assessments, and the nature of internal control testing. The audit plan then details specific procedures.
questions.tip: Audit strategy: Overall scope, timing, direction. Audit plan: Detailed procedures. Strategy guides plan development.

questions.question: Which is NOT required when obtaining an understanding of the entity and its environment?

options.B: The entity's selection and application of accounting policies
options.C: Detailed testing of all significant account balances

questions.explanation: Obtaining an understanding requires knowledge of: industry/regulatory factors, entity nature and operations, accounting policies, objectives/strategies/business risks, and internal control. Detailed testing of account balances is part of substantive procedures, not the risk assessment/understanding phase.
questions.tip: Understanding the entity: Industry, Operations, Policies, Strategies, Controls. This precedes detailed testing.

questions.question: When obtaining an understanding of the entity, the auditor should make inquiries of:

options.B: Management and others within the entity

questions.explanation: Risk assessment procedures include inquiries of management and others within the entity. 'Others' includes employees at various levels, internal auditors, in-house legal counsel, and those charged with governance. Different people may have different information relevant to risk assessment.
questions.tip: Inquiries: Management + Others (various levels, different perspectives). Not limited to senior management.

questions.question: Analytical procedures performed during planning are primarily used to:

options.A: Provide substantive evidence about account balances
options.B: Identify areas of potential risk and focus the audit
options.C: Test the operating effectiveness of controls

questions.explanation: Planning-stage analytical procedures help identify areas of potential risk that may indicate misstatement. They enhance understanding of the client's business and highlight unusual changes or relationships requiring further investigation. Substantive analytical procedures (different purpose) provide evidence about account balances.
questions.tip: Planning analytics: Risk identification, focus audit. Substantive analytics: Provide evidence. Final analytics: Overall review.

questions.question: Materiality for planning purposes is typically determined using:

options.A: A percentage of a key financial statement element like revenue, assets, or income
options.B: A fixed dollar amount set by GAAS

questions.explanation: Materiality is typically calculated as a percentage of a relevant benchmark such as total revenues, total assets, net income, or equity. The benchmark chosen depends on the entity's circumstances and users' focus. Common percentages: 0.5-1% of revenue, 1-2% of assets, 5-10% of income. Professional judgment is required.
questions.tip: Materiality benchmarks: Revenue (0.5-1%), Assets (1-2%), Income (5-10%). Choose based on entity type and user focus.

questions.question: Performance materiality is set at an amount:

options.B: Higher than overall materiality
options.D: Determined only at the completion stage

questions.explanation: Performance materiality is set at less than overall materiality to reduce the risk that aggregate uncorrected/undetected misstatements exceed overall materiality. It's used to determine the nature, timing, and extent of audit procedures. It accounts for the risk that multiple smaller misstatements could aggregate to a material amount.
questions.tip: Performance materiality < Overall materiality. Provides margin for aggregation of misstatements and undetected errors.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a significant risk requiring special audit consideration?

options.B: Revenue recognition in complex arrangements

questions.explanation: Significant risks are identified RMMs that require special audit consideration. They typically involve significant judgments, unusual transactions, fraud risk, or complex accounting. Revenue recognition (especially complex arrangements) is often a significant risk due to judgment involved. Fraud risk in revenue recognition is presumed. Routine transactions generally are not significant risks.
questions.tip: Significant risks: Require special consideration. Characteristics: Complexity, judgment, fraud risk, unusual transactions, related parties.

questions.question: Which fraud risk is presumed to exist in every audit?

options.B: Fraudulent financial reporting
options.C: Risk of material misstatement due to fraud in revenue recognition

questions.explanation: AU-C 240 (and AS 2401 for PCAOB) presumes that improper revenue recognition is a fraud risk. Unless the auditor has determined this presumption is not applicable (and documented why), revenue recognition must be addressed as a fraud risk. Management override of controls is also a presumed risk.
questions.tip: Presumed fraud risks: Revenue recognition, Management override of controls. Can be rebutted with documentation.

questions.question: The fraud triangle includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Opportunity

questions.explanation: The fraud triangle consists of three conditions generally present when fraud occurs: (1) Incentive/Pressure - motivation to commit fraud, (2) Opportunity - circumstances allowing fraud to occur, and (3) Rationalization - ability to justify the fraudulent act. Documentation is not a fraud condition.
questions.tip: Fraud triangle: Incentive (pressure), Opportunity, Rationalization. All three typically present when fraud occurs.

questions.question: Which is a fraud risk factor related to opportunity?

options.A: Significant bonuses based on financial performance
options.B: Inadequate segregation of duties
options.C: Management's excessive interest in stock price
options.D: Prior employee complaints about unethical behavior

questions.explanation: Opportunity risk factors include: inadequate segregation of duties, lack of management oversight, deficient internal controls, complex organizational structure, and high employee turnover in accounting positions. Bonuses and stock price focus are incentive factors. Complaints may indicate rationalization or culture issues.
questions.tip: Opportunity factors: Weak controls, poor segregation, inadequate oversight. Incentive factors: Bonuses, targets, financial pressures.

questions.question: Which is NOT a component of internal control under the COSO framework?

options.B: Risk assessment

questions.explanation: The five COSO internal control components are: (1) Control Environment, (2) Risk Assessment, (3) Control Activities, (4) Information and Communication, and (5) Monitoring Activities. The audit committee is part of corporate governance and relates to the control environment, but is not itself a component.
questions.tip: COSO components: Control Environment, Risk Assessment, Control Activities, Information & Communication, Monitoring. (CRIME mnemonic)

questions.question: Which factor relates to the control environment component?

options.B: Management's philosophy and operating style

questions.explanation: Control environment sets the tone at the top and includes: integrity/ethical values, commitment to competence, board/audit committee participation, management philosophy and style, organizational structure, assignment of authority, and human resource policies. Segregation, reconciliation, and physical access are control activities.
questions.tip: Control environment: Tone at the top, ethics, competence, governance. Control activities: Specific procedures and policies.

questions.question: Which is an example of a detective control?

options.A: Requiring dual signatures on checks over $10,000
options.B: Monthly bank reconciliation review
options.D: Segregation of duties between ordering and receiving

questions.explanation: Detective controls identify errors or irregularities after they occur. Bank reconciliation review is detective - it detects discrepancies after transactions occur. Preventive controls stop errors before they happen: dual signatures, passwords, and segregation of duties are all preventive controls.
questions.tip: Preventive: Stop errors before (approvals, segregation). Detective: Find errors after (reconciliations, reviews, variance analysis).

questions.question: Which is an IT general control (ITGC)?

options.B: System access security and user authentication

questions.explanation: IT general controls apply broadly to the IT environment and support application controls. ITGCs include: access security, program changes, program development, and computer operations. Input validation, automated calculations, and matching are application controls that relate to specific transaction processing.
questions.tip: ITGCs: Access security, Change management, Development, Operations. Application controls: Input, Processing, Output for specific applications.

questions.question: The required discussion among engagement team members regarding fraud risks should include:

options.B: All team members involved in the audit
options.D: The discussion is optional, not required

questions.explanation: AU-C 240 requires discussion among engagement team members about the risks of material misstatement due to fraud. The discussion should include key members and emphasize professional skepticism. It allows experienced team members to share insights and helps less experienced members understand fraud indicators.
questions.tip: Team discussion on fraud: Required, includes key members, emphasizes skepticism, shares insights across experience levels.

questions.question: An overall response to assessed risks at the financial statement level might include:

options.A: Increasing the sample size for accounts receivable
options.B: Assigning more experienced staff or providing more supervision
options.C: Performing detailed tests of inventory count

questions.explanation: Overall responses address pervasive risks affecting the financial statements as a whole. They include: emphasizing professional skepticism, assigning more experienced staff, using specialists, providing more supervision, incorporating unpredictability, and changing timing/extent generally. Specific account testing is a response at the assertion level.
questions.tip: Financial statement level responses: Staffing, supervision, unpredictability, skepticism. Assertion level: Specific procedures for accounts.

questions.question: Which assertion relates to whether recorded transactions actually occurred?

options.B: Occurrence

questions.explanation: Occurrence addresses whether transactions and events that have been recorded have actually occurred and pertain to the entity. It's the opposite of completeness (which addresses whether all transactions are recorded). Occurrence tests for overstatement; completeness tests for understatement.
questions.tip: Occurrence: Did it happen? (overstatement risk). Completeness: Is everything recorded? (understatement risk). Often tested differently.

questions.question: The assertion of 'rights and obligations' relates to:

options.B: Whether the entity holds or controls rights to assets and liabilities are the entity's obligations
options.C: Whether amounts are recorded at appropriate values

questions.explanation: Rights and obligations addresses whether the entity holds or controls the rights to assets and whether liabilities are the obligations of the entity. This is particularly relevant for assets that may be leased, held on consignment, or subject to liens, and for understanding the nature of recorded liabilities.
questions.tip: Rights & Obligations: Does entity own/control assets? Are liabilities actually owed? Important for assets not clearly owned.

questions.question: Which is a presentation and disclosure assertion?

options.B: Valuation and allocation

questions.explanation: Presentation and disclosure assertions include: occurrence/rights and obligations (disclosed events occurred and pertain to entity), completeness (all disclosures included), classification and understandability (properly classified and clearly presented), and accuracy and valuation (disclosed at appropriate amounts). Classification and understandability is unique to disclosures.
questions.tip: Disclosure assertions: Occurrence, Completeness, Classification & Understandability, Accuracy & Valuation. Focus on note disclosure quality.

questions.question: Before accepting an engagement, what communication with the predecessor auditor is required?

options.B: Communication is required; client permission needed first
options.C: The successor must obtain the predecessor's workpapers
options.D: Communication only required if the predecessor was terminated

questions.explanation: The successor auditor is required to communicate with the predecessor auditor before accepting the engagement. Client permission is needed for the predecessor to respond. Inquiries include reasons for the change, disagreements with management, fraud concerns, and any issues bearing on integrity. Workpaper review is optional.
questions.tip: Predecessor communication: Required before acceptance. Need client permission. Ask about disagreements, fraud, integrity. Workpapers optional.

questions.question: Which procedure helps identify related party transactions?

options.A: Only reviewing management's related party disclosure
options.B: Inquiry, review of documents, and evaluating unusual transactions
options.C: Confirming all transactions with third parties

questions.explanation: Identifying related parties requires multiple procedures: inquiring of management, reviewing prior-year workpapers, examining shareholder records, reviewing SEC filings and minutes, evaluating unusual or large transactions, and considering known business relationships. Relying only on management representations is insufficient.
questions.tip: Related party procedures: Multiple sources - inquiry, documents, minutes, unusual transactions. Don't rely solely on management representations.

questions.question: Regarding going concern, the auditor must:

options.A: Guarantee the entity will continue operating
options.B: Evaluate whether substantial doubt exists about going concern for one year from F/S issuance
options.C: Only consider going concern if the client raises concerns
options.D: Assess going concern for five years into the future

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates whether substantial doubt exists about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period (one year from financial statement issuance for US GAAP). The auditor considers conditions and events, evaluates management's plans, and determines appropriate reporting. This is required in every audit.
questions.tip: Going concern: Evaluate in every audit. Period: 1 year from F/S issuance. Consider conditions, management's plans, report implications.

questions.question: When evaluating accounting estimates, the auditor should:

options.B: Evaluate the reasonableness of assumptions and the estimation process
options.C: Develop independent estimates for all significant items
options.D: Only test estimates that changed from prior year

questions.explanation: For estimates, auditors evaluate: management's estimation process, assumptions used, data underlying the estimate, whether the estimate is reasonable, and consistency with other evidence. The auditor may also develop an independent expectation or evaluate management's historical accuracy. Professional skepticism is essential.
questions.tip: Estimates audit approach: Evaluate process and assumptions, develop independent expectation, review subsequent events, consider bias.

questions.question: When management uses a specialist (such as an actuary) to develop an estimate, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept the specialist's work without question
options.B: Evaluate the specialist's competence, capabilities, and objectivity
options.C: Hire their own specialist in every case
options.D: Disclaim any responsibility for the estimate

questions.explanation: When management's specialist is used, the auditor evaluates: the specialist's competence, capabilities, and objectivity; understanding the specialist's work; and whether the work is adequate audit evidence. The auditor cannot simply rely on the specialist's reputation or credentials.
questions.tip: Management's specialist: Evaluate competence, capabilities, objectivity. Understand work and evaluate adequacy. Auditor remains responsible.

questions.question: Which law would have a 'direct effect' on the financial statements?

options.B: Tax laws determining income tax expense

questions.explanation: Direct-effect laws are those with clear, direct financial statement impact - primarily tax laws and regulations affecting recorded amounts. The auditor must obtain sufficient evidence about compliance. Indirect-effect laws (environmental, safety, employment) may result in contingencies but don't directly determine F/S amounts. Different audit response for each.
questions.tip: Direct effect: Tax laws, regulations determining F/S amounts (test compliance). Indirect: Environmental, safety (be aware, follow up on identified noncompliance).

questions.question: Risk assessment documentation must include:

options.B: Key elements of understanding obtained, assessed risks, and responses to risks

questions.explanation: Documentation requirements include: discussion among team members about fraud, key elements of understanding of entity and environment including internal control, identified and assessed risks at F/S and assertion level, risks identified as significant, and the linkage between assessed risks and audit procedures (responses).
questions.tip: Risk documentation: Team discussion, understanding, assessed risks (F/S and assertion level), significant risks, risk-procedure linkage.

questions.question: Sampling risk is the risk that:

options.A: The sample is not randomly selected
options.B: The auditor's conclusion based on a sample differs from the conclusion if the entire population were tested
options.D: The auditor uses an inappropriate audit procedure

questions.explanation: Sampling risk is the risk that the auditor's conclusion based on a sample may differ from the conclusion reached if the entire population were subjected to the same procedure. It can be controlled by adjusting sample size. Non-sampling risk relates to human error or using inappropriate procedures.
questions.tip: Sampling risk: Sample conclusion ≠ Population conclusion. Controlled by sample size. Non-sampling risk: Human error, wrong procedures.

questions.question: When using internal auditors to provide direct assistance on the audit, the external auditor:

options.A: Can delegate all audit work to internal auditors
options.B: Must supervise, review, and evaluate their work
options.C: Is not responsible for work performed by internal auditors
options.D: Can only use internal auditors for clerical tasks

questions.explanation: When internal auditors provide direct assistance, the external auditor must: evaluate their competence and objectivity, supervise and review their work, and retain responsibility for conclusions. Internal auditors should not work on high-risk areas or make significant judgments. External auditor remains responsible for the audit opinion.
questions.tip: Internal auditor direct assistance: External auditor supervises, reviews, remains responsible. Limited to lower-risk areas. Evaluate competence/objectivity.

questions.question: Management representations:

options.B: Complement but do not replace other audit evidence
options.C: Are only obtained for SEC audits
options.D: Are optional at the auditor's discretion

questions.explanation: Management representations are required written statements from management acknowledging responsibility for F/S, completeness of information, and other matters. However, they complement but do not replace substantive procedures. If other evidence is obtainable, representations alone are not sufficient. They are required for all audits.
questions.tip: Management representations: Required. Complement other evidence. Don't replace substantive procedures. Written, signed by CEO/CFO.

questions.question: An engagement quality review is required for:

options.B: SEC issuer audits and certain other engagements per firm policy

questions.explanation: Under PCAOB standards, engagement quality review (EQR) is required for all SEC issuer audits. Under AICPA standards, EQR is required based on firm policy for engagements meeting specified criteria (high risk, public interest entities, etc.). The EQR partner evaluates significant judgments and the report before issuance.
questions.tip: EQR: Required for SEC issuers (PCAOB). AICPA: Based on firm policy/risk. Reviewer not engagement team member. Evaluates significant judgments.
